Comment: "Most of us don't get what its like to be a corporate CEO or a road crew member, filling potholes on the main drag, either. "

Hear, hear!  I'm an author, too.  Because of a fluke-filled life, I am a working-poor immigrant who wound up as a confidant to CEOs of billion-dollar companies and heads of government.  So I've sat in  executive suites and on private jets, and lived in basement suites and stood on lonely roads, hitchhiking hundreds of miles with two dollars in my pocket.

It comes in handy when I can write from memory what many authors can only imagine.
 
"Some writers--authors, especially . . . DO work alone, in isolation."

Yes.  There are two things commonly done all alone in a room with the door locked.  Writing is one of them.  

I am, however, a member of SF Canada, the association for professional authors and editors of Canadian science fiction.  I value the collegiality, mostly expressed by our email listserver.

Comment: A very good article however it begs the question where is the problem. It shoots down the lefts ideas, but provides no solutions of its own.

If the farmer is the supplier and the malnutritioned person as the consumer obviously there is some serious disconnect between supply and demand. When the farmer cant afford to produce his goods because he's not getting paid enough and the consumer cant afford the food the farmer makes. 

The obvious question is WTF is going on in the middle. If demand increases so should prices. Which then means every tom, dick and harry would be a farmer tomorrow. Too much supply and prices should fall to the point where people that cant make a profit pull out to decrease supply.

If the supermarkets are not making a decent profit off of these kind of price increases then 1 of 3 things. Too much regulation, inefficient business model or just a badly run business. Except for dairy I think the 1st and last are very unlikely. Might need someone with better ideas.

Comment: I think Lighthizer is the wrong person to be leading these negotiations for the US. He is too abrasive and unbending. These characteristics may work when he is dealing with steel magnates but now it is voters actually sitting across the table from him now.

If he managed by some miracle to get Mexican negotiators to accept a deal on his terms it will be portrayed next year, during their election, as the rape of Mexico by America and rejected. 

Similarly with Canada. We look for improvements to NAFTA because it is not working so well for us either. Why accept terms that only make things worse?

I think our negotiators have the measure of the man. This will be a long and tedious set of negotiations.

If Lighthizer is serious about wanting a deal he had better reconsider the end date again because at this rate he will be negotiating well into 2019. That or change his style, which is unlikely. 

A leopard cannot change its spots.

Comment: I agree.  The business leaders, AFAICS, are majority pro-NAFTA "with some adjustments", supply-management obviously being one such adjustment.  I have commented elsewhere that opening dairy and poultry to a degree would not be the end of the world.  The Yanks have put limits on our export of finished softwood lumber for a long time now.  Canadian firms have shown they can work within this, and I think a 5-10% quota on our supply-management system wouldn't be the end of the world.  Subject to appropriate labeling of course.  We opened the door to this in CETA.
The big unknown is whether Trump can terminate NAFTA on his own, or does Congress have the final say ?  This could lead to an unholy constitutional crisis smack in the middle of next year's elections.  Does Trump, or the GOP, want this ?

Comment: "NAFTA’s impact on the U.S. was moderately positive or somewhat mixed"

I would challenge that claim. If you look at GDP as the measure of an economy's health then NAFTA appears to have had little positive impact on GDP. It was constantly at around 2% year over year growth over the past 40 years and the rate hasn't accelerated since NAFTA took effect. On the other hand real take home pay in the US has stagnated over the past 25 years. 

The only positive statistic that can translate into dollars and cents in one's pocket since NAFTA took effect is the increase in capital gains. And history is showing that the so-called top 1% have been acquiring a disproportional amount of capital compared to the middle and lower income classes.

Comment: Last night I watched PBS' excellent Frontline documentary, "Putin's Revenge," which carefully outlined exactly how and why Putin meddled in our election last year to help install his puppet Trump into office. I recommend it highly. What you realize when watching that show is that major world powers, including those in Europe, are keenly aware of what happened and are reacting the way any sane, sensible person would when confronted with a porcupine - they're keeping their distance. And who can blame them? One third of our country may be isolating themselves in the Fox News information bubble, but the rest of the world is not - they know what's really going on here and they are blocking us out, as they should. It is said that in a democracy people get the government they deserve. We deserve Trump, and the rest of the world is shunning us for our egregious lapse in judgment. It is a serious lapse that we will never overcome, no matter who succeeds Trump. That kind of error is permanent.

Comment: Luke, thank you for this thoughtful commentary. When we talk about climate change we're really talking about the opportunities our children and grandchildren will have to enjoy the quality of life that we do today. The earth will persist regardless of whether we believe climate change is real or not. The question is do we want food security, energy independence, economic improvement, reduced waste, good health, resilience to natural disasters and an abundance of clean air and water. The actions each one of us can take personally to reduce emissions can directly contribute to one or more of these other benefits. So why not do it? As a state we are uniquely positioned to demonstrate carbon neutrality done right. We are also more susceptible to the direct and indirect affects of climate change. Why not take the opportunity to be a leader on the world stage and not only reduce our emissions but also reap all of the aforementioned benefits that are tied to reducing emissions?

Comment: Certainly Canada isn't the only country that has confronted this issue:

"A 2005 study, "A gap or a chasm? Attrition in reported rape cases" was the largest and most rigorous study to date commissioned by the British Home Office on UK rape crime, from the initial reporting of a rape through to legal prosecutions. The study was based on 2,643 sexual assault cases. Of these, police departments classified 8% as false reports.

The researchers noted that some of these classifications were based simply on the personal judgments of the police investigators and were made in violation of official criteria for establishing a false allegation. Closer analysis of this category applying the Home Office counting rules for establishing a false allegation and excluding cases where the application of the cases where confirmation of the designation was uncertain reduced the percentage of false reports to 3%." - Wikipedia

Comment: It's actually a given that any use of a firearm in self defense will result in the user being arrested, questioned, and detained by police, and the firearm seized as evidence.  This is something you need to expect and mentally prepare for.  It's also a good reason to know what your constitutional rights are and to tell arriving police officers just the minimum they need to know to establish what happened and why you needed to do what you did.

It bears repeating here:  never, ever forfeit the right to remain silent and never forfeit your right to an attorney.  And never sign any statement without your attorney present.  If you relinquish your rights because of a mistaken belief that everyone will believe you were the "good guy" then you prevent a mantle of constitutional protections from shielding you from police or prosecutorial error or misconduct.  These protections exist for very good reasons.  Never forget that.

Comment: My guess is, Carrington and Freeman will declare for the NFL draft; I'd be surprised if they didn't. After tearing his ACL, Olomu's 2015 draft spot fell from the projected 1st round to the 7th round, where he was the 241st overall pick.

I didn't expect another DeAnthony Thomas, but I expected more given his talent. Ducks don't have any QB recruits in the 2017 class, so keeping Jonsen and Wilson even as back-ups is necessary. Defensive linemen and linebackers are a high priority; Ducks have a few in the 2017 class. They may need to go to the JC ranks to get a few more; I have concerns about Prevot and Heard returning given Taggart's strong comments about character.

Comment: I actually work with these populations and can tell you that a larger percentage struggle with a disability of some sort, but more and more we are seeing people who are newly homeless or homeless for the first time. Often these are families who have been served a no cause eviction or sudden rent increase that forces them and their children out of their homes. The family shelter in east county is seeing 170+ family members a night. Last year this time, they were seeing 130 on a bad night. Two years ago, 100 was rare. Camping at least provides stability allowing for energy to be put towards other necessary tasks. 

It is often overlooked how much additional work those who are homeless already do beyond the average housed individual. They have to find a place to sleep, places to use the restroom, places to shower, places to sit and rest without hassle. All these things we take for granted in our homes. When it comes to the end of the day, picking up your trash becomes a low priority.

Comment: Interesting way of looking at it but in order to get that "8% return" you will need to live to age 82 to collect it vs. taking your CPP at age 68 when you actually retire. I arrived at this by comparing the theoretical total pension paid for two years (24 months) between ages 68 & 70 and the 16.8% (24 mos. x 0.7%) increase in payments if you wait until age 70 to collect. It will take you almost 12 years to recoup the 2 years of foregone CPP payments with the increase you'll get at age 70. I'd suggest that if you don't need the money, take the pension at age 68 then save and invest it in a TFSA which will supply you with a tax-free pool of capital that you can use for whatever you choose. 

Another reason to begin collecting CPP earlier rather than later is taxation. If you anticipate other forms of income increasing as you age, delayed CPP payments will incur higher income taxes. Examples: mandatory RRIF payments increase with age and dividends from blue-chip equities typically rise.

Comment: If you live outside Seattle and you do not want a heroin injection site in your city, the county ordinance is your only saving grace. Repealing it will make it possible for the Seattle King County Public Health Department to site it anywhere they please.
The judge's ruling on I-27 provides us insight. In a public health emergency, the public health  officer through the Public Health Board has incredible power.
Please remember the Tylenol tampering case (removed a product from drug store shelves) and Jack in the Box e-coli  (shut down businesses).
The county ordinance, thanks to Councilmember Balducci provides an opt out for communities. Simply put, the county won't site in your city if you opt out.
Remove that protection through passage of I-27 and the public health officer can site it wherever they want.
I-27 was crafted by the Republican Party based on polling so it could be used as a wedge issue. The irony is passing I-27 removes the one obstacle to siting an injection site here.

Comment: Stupidity problem?  Phil, this is  NOT "Lorane Hwy", which runs from Eugene to Territorial Highway--this is  Territorial Hwy  itself near the community of Lorane.  The project is long overdue, as Territorial is a dangerous, curvy narrow mix of trucks, ag equipment,  cars from tourists and locals, and of course  bicycles.
Long before 99 or I-5 were built it was the major north-south road out of the South Willamette Valley and it's becoming busier again.    In spite of its problems, for those heading towards Roseburg from the Veneta area or coming from the west, it's much faster and shorter  to drive south on historic Territorial  than driving in to Eugene then taking the freeway.        
A recent rebuilding of the bridge over the Siuslaw River took one problem from Territorial, and this planned project  to correct a  curvy area near the ridge which divides the Willamette Valley from the Siuslaw Valley   is another important step to making this beautiful drive safer and more useful.

Comment: When it comes to video games and television animation, Canadian productions are on-par with American productions in quality, and are exported world-wide. Kudos to our often over-looked video game and animation industries!

Unlike Canadian video games and animation studios that target the U.S. and international markets, Canadian live-action television and movie studios are narrowly focused on our tiny Canadian market. Comment: To the other posters. CMHC insurance does indeed benefit the banks, as their potential losses are insured. But take a moment to think about the prospective homeowner.  If there was no insurance, a lot of people would not get a mortgage and not own a home (not the home they bought anyway).

I think the government recognizes that they have been subsidizing the bank's business.  Have a look at the Twitter post below, which shows the actual rates for insurance. The 'increase' may look small, but it is actually the lower leverage mortgages that experience the biggest increase in mortgage insurance rate.   Banks have been using CMHC insurance to reduce the cost of their own borrowing, even for mortgages below 20% leverage. It will cost them a lot more with this change to continue the practice.

The government has also mused about having a 'deductable' where the bank eats part of any loss. A less likely outcome after these increases.

https://twitter.com/i/web/status/821349107268784129

Comment: "The sun’s harmful UV rays can have the same risk rating on cloudy days with temperatures in the 60s as on sunny days, she said.

I've heard similar claims dozens of times before, and yet despite my pale white Irish and German descended complexion, I've spent entire days outside in light overcasts and never gotten so much as a hint of a tan, yet on these sunny spring days before I've got much of a tan (like today, except this year I got an early tan on vacation), an hour or two outside is an almost certain burn.

Comment: Yes indeed - and our system is very much built on the premise that is is "better to let 10 guilty men go free than to let 1 innocent man be jailed". Other criminal systems do not take that approach - such as in China where the conviction rate is something like 98% and trials are basically a foregone conclusion heavily stacked in the prosecution's favour - the philosophy there is to maximize convictions at the expense of locking up many innocent people in the process. It is very much a legal expression of a more collectivist culture and political philosophy. 

In Canada, individualism and individual rights against government power come first, so the system heavily favours the accused, both with the presumption of innocence, and the fact that the entire burden of proof rests on the Crown (i.e. the accused doesn't have to prove his innocence in court because he is already considered innocent and it is entirely on the Crown to bring the case for guilt).

Comment: Take it from a retired editor, words matter. My objection isn't to the adjective "illegal," I take issue with the noun "alien" being applied to other human beings. These immigrants are hardly "aliens" (from old English and French: "belonging to another"), though they technically may be termed "illegal." Immigrants reflect the roaming nature of humans on Earth generally. Immigrants have always "belonged" in America, though Americians often have not welcomed them initially. We are here because our ancestors were the wanderers, willing to take a chance on an unknown place to better their future or escape persecution. Immigrants (yes, even so-called Native Americans) originally came from elsewhere. Accurate description demands objectivity. Those who don't understand the difference are the reason I've always had a job.

Comment: In the pits that capture manure under factory-scale hog farms, a gray, bubbly substance began appearing at the surface of the fecal soup. 

The problem is menacing: 

As manure breaks down, it emits toxic gases like hydrogen sulfide and flammable ones like methane, and trapping these noxious fumes under a layer of foam can lead to sudden, disastrous releases and even explosions. 

According to a 2012 report from the University of Minnesota, by September 2011, the foam had “caused about a half-dozen explosions in the upper Midwest…one explosion destroyed a barn on a farm in northern Iowa, killing 1,500 pigs and severely burning the worker involved.”

Comment: The battle cry of the French Revolution was "Liberty and Equality". In fact you can never have both completely. Outright liberty would lead to greater inequality. Outright equality would lead to less liberty. The dilemma is of course is where the right balance lies. That is the dilemma for governments everywhere. Those that insisted on complete equality only ensured that everyone was equally poor, i.e. the former Soviet Union, Cuba etc. (Although 'party members' were consistently better off.) They were a complete failure. At some point along the continuum of 'tax fairness' lies a tipping point of negative consequences. It seems that our current government is seeking that tipping point. Of course that is necessitated by spending more than the revenue allows and going into deficits. Our government has a spending problem not a revenue problem.

Comment: Republicans (ironic, given how mercilessly they mocked Democrats for doing so for eight years with Obama) are misplacing their hope on "hope". Their argument, it seems, is "how can the President be accused of criminal hope?". And members of the media have fallen for the misdirection, seemingly extracting and repeating the word "hope" out of the President's purported request of Comey.

But the President did not say "I hope Michael Flynn is exonerated". He said "I hope you can see your way clear to letting this go, to letting Flynn go". There is a difference between saying to my wife "I hope we have a delicious dinner" and saying "I hope you can see your way to making a delicious dinner". There is a difference between saying to your child's teacher "I hope Johnny gets an A in your class" and saying "I hope you can see your way to giving Johnny an A in your class".

Republicans, I hope Trump doesn't destroy our democracy. I hope you can see your way to impeaching Trump.

Comment: "That is not how organized labor views the world, nor is it how the Catholic Church views the world."

I guess you missed the comments of the various labor leaders Trump met with yesterday gushing over how much respect they had been shown. Trump is a buffoon, but on this issue, he is skillfully exploiting some tensions within the labor coalition. It is no accident that he revived the Keystone & Dakota pipelines on the same day he announced pulling out of the TPP; labor has also supported those projects.

Finally, while I support TPP & Free Trade generally, & am alarmed by certain elements of Trump's "nationalism", I don't see the logic in the leap from opposing TPP to "the kind of jingoist, nativist nationalism Trump is peddling"? Is a "Buy America" effort nativist? Nor do I really accept the assertion that the Catholic Church opposes some of the economic protectionist measures he is floating (such as a tax, for example, on corporations that move operations to foreign nations).

Comment: Argyle,

Yes, francophones comprise approximately one-third of the total population of the Ottawa-metro Gatineau region.  However, a lot of the federal public service is outside of the NCR.  According to gov.ca stats for 2016, 38,000 in Quebec and NB, and over 100,000 in the rest of the country.  Any way we slice it, ROC anglophones and allophones have a much lower representation per capita in the federal public service than francophones.  I would suggest that this is due, in large part, to the very low level of bilingualism among non-francophones in ROC and that that low level is inevitable given lack of viable opportunity/need for these groups to use French.  It is problematic for the country's governance if many of the best and brightest of such a large portion of its population (over 70%) do not see participation in federal civil service or government as a viable option.

Comment: "self-deprecating modesty" is about as close as it comes.  My American friends chuckle over how polite we are, and it is a truism that no Canadian artist -- be it literary, musical, visual, or otherwise -- is really taken seriously unless they are embraced in another country. 

We don't tend to brag about our achievements, and while we are somewhat guilty of revisionist history, we certainly don't tell the whoppers that Europeans or Americans do.  Even our National Anthem refrains from boasting (with the possible exception of the French lyrics, with their "plus brillants exploits") -- instead we ask God to keep our land glorious and free and only promise to stand on guard.

I have to confess that I am unreasonably proud of both our achievements and our modesty, but like a good Canadian, I don't like to talk about it all that much.

Comment: I'm sure that you really don't know what the circumstances of the departure of CU and Nebraska really were. Although it happened years ago, let me remind you.

1) CU was going to leave for the Pac 10 regardless. CU (and its President and Board of Regents) always wanted to be affiliated with the Pac 10 Universities instead of schools in Kansas and Iowa. When the Big 12 was created, CU never really had any affiliation with the Texas schools (the Big 12 South).

2)Nebraska's problem wasn't that Texas was taking too much revenue, Nebraska was opposed to EQUAL revenue sharing. Nebraska literally said at the time that they wouldn't stay in a conference that split revenues equally. 

3) Nebraska was opposed to a conference championship game. Nebraska was mad that Texas wouldn't allow them to keep recruiting Juco partial academic qualifiers.

4) Nebraska, like CU, got a better offer to join a more stable conference. The Big 10 is undeniably more stable than the Big 12.

Comment: Do your jobs, or lose your jobs. I'm disgusted with all of them, regardless of party affiliation. 

"The Legislature's 90-day deadline, which came and went in mid-April, was set in a 2006 citizens initiative. And since it's a law and the Legislature writes laws, lawmakers are free to disregard it."

Sure, they're free to disregard a deadline set by a citizens initiative. But actions have consequences, even if they're actions that don't violate the law. Go ahead, disregard the deadline - again. But don't think for a minute that the public will disregard what you've done. I'm keeping track of who's working, and who's dragging their posteriors. When election day rolls around, I'm going to remember the arrogant dereliction of duty that has become business as usual for our legislature.

And I think it's time for some new laws about legislators' pay and per diem. Fine them a day's pay and per diem for every day past the regular session that they don't get their jobs done.

Comment: Do you know why hospitals are better staffed and more modern?  Because their budgets are astronomical, they have additional sources of revenue and they don't have to run a balanced budget and can always plead for more funding.

The reason your GPs office is more rundown and the staff likely isn't cheery is because all staffing, equipment and capital costs all comes out of your doctor's gross billing numbers that the media loves to quote as salary. 

So most offices have to run understaffed, can't afford to pay employees well, often can't afford nurses to help with patient care and can't afford nice furniture, flat-screen TVs, nice artwork, frills.

Do you have any idea how inefficient and expensive primary care would become if everything was brought under the hospital's umbrella?  Imagine the equivalent of an emergency department visit experience everytime you needed a physical, forms completed or a prescription refill.

Comment: I think all members of congress/senate should be limited to 2 consecutive terms (12 years total).  However, I think that term should be extended if that person is elected to a main leadership role within their party (such as Minority/Majority Leader), at which point the person is granted 2 additional terms.  This would limit the maximum time a person can serve in the House/Senate to 24 years - which, in my opinion, is more than enough time for a person to be in that type of position.  If they are interested in staying in DC, they can run for a different elected position.  

This process would keep the blood fresh in DC, and get out the stale old partisan politicians who have refused to cross the aisle their entire life.  It would also force the public to be slightly more involved in politics instead of just voting for the same guy for every election just due to name recognition.

Comment: There are several problems: helping farmers to survive, producing food for now and the future, and not abandoning the land to become a dust bowl.
It is to everyone’s interests to solve these problems so the use of state and federal aid is appropriate. The solution is in technology that will allow significant increases in production with less water and land use.  Much of the technology exists but continued research and development is needed.
While farmers still have income they need to start to make the capital investments needed. Instead of $100k for a tractor they need to invest that capital in a bioreactor with state and federal help. We need to set up programs to plan this transition.  An algal bioreactor can produce more cattle feed with less energy and water than large areas of corn or alfalfa.  Wheat flour can be produces without concern about drought, locusts, or hail with less land and water.This is a good article so hopefully they will get into alternative production methods.

Comment: According to the American pragmatic philosophers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the product of serious communal inquiry is reason--the more inquiry, the more reasonable things become.  The pragmatists would have liked the P4C Lori Walker Peroff describes because it teaches skills required by a community of inquirers.

The idea of communal inquiry faces strong headwinds nowadays.  @frank_96740 points to the chilling effect of the left's PC, while the left is alarmed by the right's fake Internet news and the President-elect's dismissive rhetoric.  

I think this is a case where both the right and the left have correctly identified habits corrosive to communal inquiry and the production of reason.  

Hopefully, in our politically divided nation, worthy efforts like the P4C described by Ms. Peroff will be widely promoted and supported.

Comment: @outsider77 and @ScienceDuck

With respect, ‘limited impact’ and ‘not real job producers’ are characterization not consistent with the data. The Lane County Tech sector (Oregon Employment Department definition) is now home to 427 tech companies. The vast majority of these companies individually are small to mid-sized in terms of employment, but in total employ nearly 5,000 people. For reference, that total employment numer is ~25% larger than wood products, which is another important sector.  The tech sector not only has the highest average wage of any (total payroll ~$350,000,000), but was forecasted to grow faster than all other sectors: 19 percent between 2012 and 2022, compared to just 15 percent for all other industries. Tech sector growth is exceeding forecasts, Lane county has already added 500 of the 774 expected new jobs in the first three years of that ten year period. In fact, new (software) tech jobs are impactful and these companies do produce jobs.

Comment: ALERT ALTERNATIVE - sad that Chaput steals this title from an excellent book of my adolescence - Stranger in a Strange Land.  Advise reading this Heinlen novel and not wasting time with Chaput's Napa Valley propaganda:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stranger_in_a_Strange_Land

Stranger in a Strange Land is a 1961 science fiction novel by American author Robert A. Heinlein. It tells the story of Valentine Michael Smith, a human who comes to Earth in early adulthood after being born on the planet Mars and raised by Martians. The novel explores his interaction with—and eventual transformation of—Terran culture. In 2012, the US Library of Congress named it one of 88 "Books that Shaped America".

The title "Stranger in a Strange Land" is an allusion to the phrase in Exodus 2:22

Comment: The promise of AI, specifically machine learning, to perform legal functions is still a ways off. These systems need to be taught how to read law, how to interpret them and finally how to make judgements.

Modern AI is REALLY good at recognizing patterns. So if you show it vast amounts of data (like cases and results) it can learn the pattern and apply it. Part of the challenge with many of these cases is that they are one offs with not precedent to guide the judges (or machine).

I suspect we still are a couple of decades away from having a robot judge.

Comment: As free citizens of the United States whether or not to obey a police order depends upon what the officer orders and under what circumstances the order occurs. Police do not have unlimited authority to order us around, and we are not universally obligated to obey what police order. Police officers often have no authority to order people to do what the officers want, such as telling people to stop recording them or to leave a certain area. Officers are authorized to use reasonable force to fulfill their duties, but there is no blanket rule allowing police to simply order us to do whatever they like.

Comment: "The children went to high school with us in Ashcroft, rather than in Church Run Schools, back in the late 1960s.'

In June 1961, our grade 9 class in Vernon Jr. High was ready to go to Vernon High come Sept.  Couldn't wait! Except Wally.  Wally was a First Nations kid--very nice, quiet, unassuming kid. He quietly told us that he wasn't going to High School. "Ya gotta go, Wally! Ya gotta go!"  He shook his head.  "Well, whaddya gonna do?"  
"Go back to the reserve," he said.  
"But you HAVE to finish high school,"  we said.

No, he didn't.  And so...he didn't.  The lure of the reserve--the pull of family ties--was too, too strong.  And so, we--his classmates, Vernon itself, heck, who knows, maybe even the country--lost Wally.  

That's a long time ago.  But I'll never forget that day in Grade 9...

Comment: So you are now the judge of every divorce and annulment that takes place in the U.S.---never mind the rest of the world?  ALL people don't just 'move on.'  Many go through serious trauma as a result of divorce.  And yes, divorce in Christ's time had the man with all the power on his side and the wife with nothing to support her.  All he had to do was to give his wife a writ---and she was history.  If her father was still alive--she could ask to come home---but he didn't have to admit her.  And if he did, he could beat her for bringing shame to the family name.  Most women had to resort to prostitution to survive.  Jesus was very much aware of this.
Today, women have much more to say about divorce---but that still doesn't eradicate the heart-ache, and mental distress many people endure. The 20-page booklet that is expected to be filled out in detail, going to the diocesan tribunal and discussing this---with a stranger, are often more than most people can take.

Comment: It's pretty rare for the side who lost the war to have standing monuments to honor their leaders.  It's even more rare for the side who lost to have said monuments continue to be constructed nearly a century after loss without the intention of sending a message.  

Robert E. Lee himself opposed the construction of confederate monuments, citing:
“As regards the erection of such a monument as is contemplated, my conviction is, that however grateful it would be to the feelings of the South, the attempt in the present condition of the Country, would have the effect of retarding, instead of accelerating its accomplishment; [and] of continuing, if not adding to, the difficulties under which the Southern people labour.”

Jonathan Horn, the author of the Lee biography surmised:
“He was worried that by keeping these symbols alive, it would keep the divisions alive.”

Perhaps we should construct a Robert E. Lee statue for him so accurately predicting the future.

Comment: There is something wrong with the narrative on this. If it is truly as barbaric and causes unremitting lifelong pain, why would veterinarians do it? I've had them all my life until a month ago. 

If it were as terrible as some opponents say, it seems that euthanasia would be recommended if the only way to keep the cat is declawing. But it is considered to be preferable to euthanising a problem cat who won't stop scratching inappropriately. 

I have to wonder if there are some vets that do it better than others? Studies apparently do not support a connection between declawing and bad behavior. I think there is a lot of misinformation in the arguments.

Comment: There are far fewer guns than reported in the recent news articles.  Hawaii police departments register firearms.  However, the departments do not have the ability to track any firearm that leaves the state.  In other words, there is no way the police can "un-register" a firearm.  Many of the firearms registered in Honolulu are military personnel who dutifully obey Hawaii's gun registration laws.  However, when these same soldiers, sailors, marines or airmen are rotated to a new duty station out side of Hawaii, guess what most of those guns leave the state, but remain "registered" with HPD.

So before all you liberals and gun control advocates start freaking out on Facebook or Instagrams, there are a lot less firearms residing in Hawaii than anyone realizes.  I would venture to guess that it would be lucky if we even have 200,000 firearms actually in Hawaii.

Comment: I think states are stupid to enact their own term limits under the current system....but I'm all for term limits becoming a nationwide policy.

If it were left to me, a Senate term would be 8 years, 6 for president, and 4 for the House.  Someone can serve one of each, and then they're out.  This way they spend the bulk of their time doing their job, not running for office.  I would also require someone to resign their current position once they declare their candidacy.  In other words, you're either a Senator or a presidential candidate....not both.  That way, we don't get 16 candidates from one party.

Comment: Some myth-dispelling about the myth-dispelling.

The "earliest Americans" weren't the Puritans. They were the perfectly mainstream Anglicans at Jamestown. They did not have an aversion to Christmas.

Liberals do not hate Christmas crèches because they're Christian; they hate them because they're kitschy. 

"Happy Holidays" did not originally mean "Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanza." It meant "Christmas and New Year."  It meant, "Buy presents AND rum for egg nog."

There is nothing anti-Christian about gift-giving at Christmastime. It's the time of the year that people spend thinking about other people and what they like and how to please them. What's un-Christian about that?

There is no War on Advent. There are two holidays called Christmas: Christian Christmas and Secular Christmas. Christian Christmas has an Advent and Secular Christmas does not. A lot more people celebrate Secular Christmas than Christian Christmas. They're not making war on Advent; they just have no use for it.

Comment: Correct. Toronto never experienced the hollowing out of the city core. However, the trend in which the 'middle class' was being pushed further from the core has been underway for decades. 

David Hulchanski's "Three Cities of Toronto" work has tracked the trend over the course of several decades.

http://www.urbancentre.utoronto.ca/pdfs/curp/tnrn/Three-Cities-Within-Toronto-2010-Final.pdf

https://www.thestar.com/news/city_hall/2015/01/28/torontos-income-gap-continues-to-widen-finds-u-of-t-expert.html

The current real estate speculation is just kicking it into hyper-drive, but the trends are not simply explained by the speculation driver. Hulchanski notes that what we see in urban segregation is driven by overall trends in income inequality, speculation amplifies.

Comment: Commenter, I disagree about lowering the rate bit by bit. The rate has been too high for the better part of a decade and is a major driver of the huge additional contributions being asked of state agencies when the actual returns fall short of the assumed rate.

No one can predict the future, but we cannot properly evaluate the size of the pension problem without a conservative assumed rate. If it turns out to be too low, the consequences are far less severe than if it is too high year after year.

Comment: Him being proud of his work is immaterial.  You keep bringing that up and it doesn't matter in this situation.  What you are really lacking here is what is fundamental about the argument. An artist can pick and choose who commissions him to perform his work.  He can't pick and choose who buys his work.   That is the fundamental difference you are missing.  The only question here is, is he an artist?  That's what it comes down to.  All the other rabbit holes you are introducing don't pertain, such as why he can choose to pick and choose who he allows to commission his work.  It can be based upon religion or randomness.  And I am not arguing that he can or can't nor am I supporting either side.  I am merely stating that the basis for his argument stands a chance of winning.  I'm not sure why you don't get this.

Comment: I grew up in a small middle-class town in the mid-west, population of 5,000 and has not changed much in 100 years. Everyone used it to get into our small little downtown which had a grocery, hardware, meat, clothing, shoe store, etc.  No one needed a car because of (GASP) public transportation being conveniently available.  All the dedicated lines for this were removed long ago and buildings have been placed where they once were.  Why did we give this up?

Comment: How great to see Brooks' discussion of John Reed, one of the most significant writers ever to come out of our state of Oregon.  It was once my pleasure to put my hand on his place in the Kremlin Wall at Red Square.  His vivid descriptions of Russia's tumult, along with those of his partner Louise Bryant (a UO grad) are as dramatic as historical writing can be.
Trouble is, in his fantastic book on the revolution, Ten Days That Shook the World, while he was right about the Bolsheviks' passion and vision, he was wrong about their ultimate goals.  Reed was happy to see them sweep away Kerensky's democratic collection of Socialists and Cadets, which he felt was too disorganized to fight off a Right-Wing Counter Coup.  
What Reed failed to see in time were the Bolsheviks' own bad features, their brutality and authoritarianism.  As Reed died prematurely in Russia in 1920 we'll never know if he'd have turned against Lenin.
And WE need a passion and vision if we are to preserve democracy today.

Comment: I sent an e-mail to Governor Poloz on June 5 to personally inform him of the disinformation the Bank of Canada is disseminating about Eurostat’s plans to reform the way owner-occupied housing (OOH) is calculated in its HICP. So far he hasn’t even deigned to acknowledge it. Contrary to what was published in the autumn 2015 Bank of Canada Review, Eurostat is not “currently conducting a pilot study for the euro area based on the net acquisition[s] approach, and has never done so. Eurostat pilots for an OOHPI (OOH price index) series went through four phases, from 2001 to 2011, expanding from five to 29 countries. In each phase countries that were not In the euro area were involved. From December 2014 forward 30 countries, the EU members plus Iceland and Norway are supposed to calculate quarterly OOHPI series. Indices are only still unavailable for four of these 30 countries: Croatia, Greece, Iceland and the Netherlands.

Comment: There are roughly 1.4 million aboriginal people in Canada, of which roughly half live on reservations. There are over 600 FN  groups, a few have made settlements with the government, and there have been some successes here (by that, I mean economically sustaining and providing job opportunities for their local communities). Do these groups share their best practices with other FN? The Truth and Reconciliation report has numerous calls to action, and Trudeau has committed to fulfilling all of these. With isolated reserves of 2,000 or less scattered far from  small cities with decent healthcare, schooling, it makes more sense to relocate to these cities & beef up services here (ie. Wpg, Thunder Bay,Timmins). Better internet connection is a Trudeau prospect but I suspect the increase in youth suicides is due to youth awareness of opportunities in the south. Economics is not on the side of many remote reserves. If we can resettle 300,000 immigrants each year, we can do better.

Comment: We installed photovoltaic panels and a small wind turbine in 2003 at our cabin. It was our full time home for three years. We didn't receive any federal income tax incentives as there weren't any then. Didn't matter because our system penciled out for us. We ran microwave ovens, vacuum cleaners, hair dryers, coffee makers, electric refrigerators, satellite tv, lights, an electric toilet seat heater in our outhouse, and various wall wart chargers. During the full time years we averaged less than 100 hours per year on our gas generator charger. During our part time living there we average less than 20 hours per year using the gas generator charger. From March to October we rarely use it at all. Without those renewables we would be averaging about 4 hours per day recharging the batteries with the gas generator.

A harbinger was invented in 1890 and the current versions evolved and were mass produced in the late 1940’s and have always been available to the public (note the “47” in AK-47 stands for 1947, the year the firearm went into production). Comment: Paul, I'm starting to get you---Or maybe you're mellowing with age.  

I could say you're making a false comparison between Togiak and Mat Su, and perhaps you really are, but you seem to know that:  Why pick on Togiak?  

It's hard to believe you really know what it's like there, but the analogy you're holding up is worth looking at---Can the rules of evidence and due process, tenets central to our criminal justice system, be faithfully and, more to the point, effectively applied in the environment of a native village of a few hundred people, where everyone knows everyone else, and an impartial jury is out of the question?

The answer is that of course they can---Just because Togiak's Tribal Council doesn't want to make their process available to people like you, doesn't mean there isn't one.  The jury system was invented in a very similar culture of tiny northern towns, a tribal culture, and forwarded to the benefit of the world.

COALBED METHANE STREAM DEPLETION STUDY

Comment: Although I disagree with some of the sentiments expressed in this piece by this fine writer, I do agree that Native Alaskans should hold on furiously to their culture, as should all peoples who live in places dominated by foreign culture, because if they don't, those foreign cultures will supplant their own. I am an American of Irish descent, and I appreciate the de-anglicization of place names in Ireland and the regrowth of the Irish language there. But, let's recognize that the domination of one culture over another is not unique to the Americas and not unique to the time of European dominance in world affairs. The Chinese dominated Vietnam for over a century, as they now dominate Tibet. Arabs, Berbers, and Turks dominated much of southern Europe for centuries. There are many, many more examples of the same. In fact, the view that only Europeans and their descendants engage in cultural domination is itself a result of ethnocentrism and its dehumanizing "noble savage" fantasy.

Comment: Among those "struggling downtown businesses" are existing hotels. Does Port Angeles have a shortage of rooms for rent? What about this nondescript big box is unique and attractive? If it made a gesture towards invoking a traditional longhouse, with a native art theme and providing open-fire salmon bakes and canoe rides, with native dancing and crafts exhibits I could see this as an addition to rather than competition for existing hostelry. As it is it evokes a more Motel 6 theme. Nothing wrong with that, of course, and the tribe certainly has a right to compete with other low-end lodging, but let's not kid ourselves that this is going to be a job-creator. Comment: Typical statutes might differentiate between the two as follows:

First Degree: intent to kill + premeditation and deliberation

Second Degree:  intentional killing; by extremely reckless conduct, intent to cause serious bodily harm, Deadly weapon doctrine 

I could easily imagine that this cop did not set out to work that day with the intent to kill anybody, nor did he do any planning for the murder, making it hard to get a conviction for First Degree Murder. 

But, a pretty good case might be made that the killing was "spur of the moment" (perhaps out of anger?), or something like that.  

So had the charge been second degree, I think the cop may have had a tougher go in court.  A conviction would require a lot of time in jail, possibly for life.  So did the prosecutor overstep on this one?

Comment: Good comment - however, the Liberal child tax benefit is essentially the Conservative tax benefit with some changes  (i.e. a larger payout per family, the rich excluded, different taxation rules).

It was renamed purely for political branding reasons (the Liberals wanted to stamp it as "their" program - fair enough- it's politics as usual).

Make no mistake, however.  The return of the so-called "baby bonus" was and is a Harper policy.  And a sensible one.  Child care or child raising isn't health care, the latter where you essentially must see a doctor/nurse to access medical care.  Child care can be parents, relatives, daycare or pre-school - money can be used in a variety of different ways for the family or child.

Recall in the 2005/2006 campaign a Liberal spokesman derided it as "beer and popcorn" popcorn money.

It's good to see that the Liberals got with the program, although their budgeting leaves much to be desired.

Comment: If you think it's bad based on Rob's numbers, think again.  He forgot a whole bunch of other costs:

1)   Closing costs at time of purchase - i.e. legal, home inspection, land transfer tax, etc
2)  Mortgage insurance - because the borrower only paid 10% down
3)  Selling costs - the owner would only net around $750k because the real estate agent will take their cut
4)  Opportunity costs - long term return of 8-10% on stocks compounded over 25 years 

If you understand finance, you'll see that home ownership is a terrible investment (in the current market).

Comment: The faster it is, the more useful it is.

Most people need to drive an hour to get to the airport and you need to be there a recommended hour ahead of time for the security theatre, a possible half hour wait for you checked bags, and another hour to your hotel in most locations. That's three and a half more hours on top of how long your flight takes!

So that flight from Toronto to Montreal, even though the air time is only a little over an hour, home-to-hotel is actually more like 5 hours.

At HSR speeds it is less than 2 hours travel time and the train stations are in town rather than an hour outside so home→station and station→hotel is 15 minutes, 30 at most on a bus from the edge of town? So three hours at the most. And no damnable security theatre lines like at the airport!

Hyperloop (when it's finally possible) speeds would cut that trip to 90 minutes max. Imagine living in Montreal and commuting to Toronto for work.

Comment: It depends on how the policy is written:

"Many life insurance policies, just like any other insurance coverage, come with certain exclusions that null and void any benefits should you expire in a certain way, i.e., suicide. However, there can be fine print attached to that exclusion. Some policies will pay benefits even if the policyholder committed suicide, but the policyholder would have had to committed suicide after holding the life insurance policy for two to three years depending on the carrier."

"Some policies come with a separate exclusion that addresses non-disclosure of mental health and/or drug or alcohol addiction/dependencies. If you have a history of serious depression and your life insurance carrier doesn’t know, you run the risk of eliminating any benefits if you commit suicide. Leaving out information like this allows insurance companies to deny benefits based on a contestability clause."

http://www.insurancequotes.org/life/the-truth-about-suicide-life-insurance/

Comment: To the Apassingok family, & especially to Chris:I applaud & envy you & Savoonga for keeping alive the highest and best of Inupiak traditions of hard work, subsistence skills & community values!   
Non-rural Alaskans & especially non-alaskans have, sadly, all lost the very close ties to the rich subsistence values of sharing & community their very own families and smaller communities once would have always understood- and would have shared with the families of Savoonga.
Long ago I was blessed enough to have been allowed to start the first Molly Hootch one-teacher school- I did so in an old shop in Savoonga. In that time & place we all valued each other, and I was allowed by umiak captains to  join with their crews on summer whaling and winter walrus hunts. Those shared times helped shape the best of who I am as a human today.
The joy of the entire community in a successful hunt & the shared effort & song in beaching the harvest, & then dividing & sharing it are unforgettable. Thank you!

Comment: It depends on what you mean by "learn." If you mean: figure out what the teacher wants, memorize it, regurgitate it on a test, forget about it, sure they "learn." Then they get to university and are outraged to discover that doing that gets them Fs and Ds. I know; I teach university.

On essays, I devote a whole class to my essay expectations and provide a detailed handout on them. Nonetheless, 35% - 45% of students in most of my classes get an F or a D on the first essay--almost always because they ignored requirements (one student last term said to me, "But I didn't think having a thesis was all that important"). 

I give my students up to 2 single-spaced typed pages of comments on essays. Most improve, but a surprising number repeat the same mistakes in a second essay; they aren't used to paying attention to feedback and applying it. If this experiment gets them to take ownership of their own work, pay attention to feedback, and apply it to future work, it's worth it.

Comment: This  reminds me of when I was a student in a "Problems of Democracy" class at Marshfield High School back in 1953.  As a class project, two of us  took  extracts from the  Declaration of Independence, placed them on a petition, and went door to door in Coos Bay-
As I recall, the sections we included were:
"whenever any form of government becomes destructive to these ends, it is the right of the people to alter or to abolish it, and to institute new government, laying its foundation on such principles, and organizing its powers in such forms, as to them shall seem most likely to effect their safety and happiness."
Also:
"But when a long train of abuses and usurpations, pursuing invariably the same object, evinces a design to reduce them under absolute despotism, it is their right, it is their duty, to throw off such government, and to provide new guards for their future security."
Almost nobody signed, and  the resulting newspaper headline was "THOMAS JEFFERSON DECLARED COMMUNIST."

Comment: Trudeau and the Liberals were in power at the start of the 1984/85 fiscal year and wrote the budget for the year.  Mulroney won the election and took office right at the very end of that fiscal year.

Yes, I know the CBC incorrectly attributes this to Mulroney, but you really need to look at who wrote the budget to determine who is most responsible for the deficit, and in the case of the 1984/85 fiscal year that was Pierre Trudeau and the Liberals.

I specifically mention that year because it is the largest post-WWII deficit in Canadian history in terms of percent of GDP at 8.1%.  By contrast the $55.6B deficit for the 2009/10 fiscal year, while the largest in nominal dollars, was only 3.5% of GDP.

Comment: Fake news was one of only several factors that elected the combover king.  Disgust with the status quo in Washington propelled an ignorant buffoon to the most powerful post in the world.

Fake news has always been around, but historically, it was confined to tabloids and lunatic fringe weeklies.  Because advertising and sales revenues have plummeted, traditional forms of journalism are under siege.

Were they always unbiased and truthful?  No, the fool’s paradise no more existed then than now.  But no one has the resources to put qualified people in news bureaus around the world any longer, meaning we are getting poorly researched drivel from hacks.

If a financial shot in the arm will improve the fourth estate, and if funding can be squeezed out of the online advertising monoliths who pay little to no tax I am for it.  It won’t fix all of our information woes, but it might help the goal of intelligent discourse upon which democracy is founded.

Comment: This article may give the impression that Rasmuson Foundation is in disagreement of Governor Walker’s efforts to address the state budget gap. To the contrary, we applaud his boldness in coming forward with a comprehensive plan featuring a combination of budget cuts, new revenues and using some reserves. We also applaud the legislature for making the budget the focus in the last days of the session.

As a Foundation working to improve the quality of life in Alaska, we hope the plan that is adopted is equitable in what it demands from Alaskans and puts the State on a path to long-term sustainability. According to this research, if only a portion of the Governor’s plan is adopted – budget cuts and Permanent Fund changes – without new revenues, the impact will fall mostly on middle-income working families and the poor, and barely, if at all, on the wealthy.

We offer this research in order to help answer important questions, not to support or oppose any specific plan or its author.

Comment: It is less them filtering, than them throttling.  Comcast got caught a few years back throttling content from Apple and Netflix, whose streaming services compete with Comcast's TV service.  Netflix paid quite a bit of money to Comcast to get their content streamed faster.  Before they paid, you would still get the content, but it would just come down much slower, so the resolution wouldn't be as good, or the video would stutter.  

The idea of net-neutrality is that your internet service should be a dumb pipe.  If you pay for a 200 Mbps service for 1TB, then you should get that service, period, not have it slowed down for some content and faster for others.  That is the essence of net-neutrality.
